text.title: Pal Kastrioti
text.head: Pal Kastrioti
text.p: Pal Kastrioti (fl. 1383–1407) was an Albanian nobleman attested in c. 1383 as the lord of two villages, Sina and Lower Gardi. According to Gjon Muzaka Pal had three sons: Konstantin, Alexius and Gjon Kastrioti, the latter who was Skanderbeg's father.
text.head: Family
text.p: The first person to be mentioned as a Kastriot in historical documents,[1] was a ruler (kephale or castellan in contemporary sources) of the Kanina in 1368.[2][3][4] which belonged to the Principality of Valona.[5] It is assumed by Ivan Božić that Pal's father received his estates in Albania from Serbian Emperor Dušan after he captured Berat, Valona and Kanina in 1345.[3] Heinrich Kretschmayr asserts that Pal Kastrioti, the father of Gjon Kastrioti and grandfather of Skanderbeg, was in fact Kephale of Kanina in 1368.[6] According to French historian Alain Ducellier and Albanian scholar Fan S. Noli, there is no proof that Kephale Kastriot was the ancestor of Skanderbeg.[7][8] Noli further notes that, according to Andrea Engjell Flav Komneni, prince of Drisht and Bar, Skanderbeg's great-grandfather and Pal Kastrioti's father was Konstandin Kastrioti.[9] German historian, Franz Babinger, argued in the 1960s that there seems to have been a scientific consensus that kephale Branilo Kastrioti, Skanderbeg's great-grandfather and the earliest known ancestor of Skanderbeg, was of Serbian origin.[10] Nevertheless, per Harry Hodgkinson that claim is result of a mistaken reading of medieval manuscript written in Serbian by Karl Hopf.[11] Medieval Albanian historian and nobleman Gjon Muzaka, also, in his chronicle characterizes George Kastriote Skanderbeg as "of Serbian nature".[12] Most Albanian historians insist that the Kastrioti family were ethnic Albanians from Kastriot in Mat.[13][14][15]

Pal Kastrioti had three sons: Konstantin[A], Alexius and Gjon Kastrioti[4][16] who was Skanderbeg's father.[3][17] Alexius Kastrioti controlled three villages.[18] Konstantin Kastrioti was protovestiarios of Sina (Serina) near Durrazo.[19] According to Venetian document discovered by Karl Hopf his title was Lord of Cerüja castle (Latin: dominus Serinae).[20]

Gjon Kastrioti was most famous of three brothers. Like many other noblemen from Albania, he became an Ottoman vassal since 1385.[21] He supported Bayezid I in the Battle of Ankara in 1402[22] and revolted against the Ottomans during the Albanian Revolt of 1432-1436 led by Gjergj Arianiti.[23]
text.head: Territory
text.p: At the end of 14th century Pal had the title "segnior de Signa et de Gardi-ipostesi", as the holder of the two villages of Sina (Albanian: Sinë) and Lower Gardi (Albanian: Gardhi i Poshtëm).[1][24] According to some sources the villages he governed were located on the mountain of Qidhna northwest of Debar.[25] Those two villages were granted to Pal by Balša II, the lord of Zeta around 1383 as a fief.[26] The decline of the Balšić family marked the ascendancy of the Kastrioti family.[1] Gjon Kastrioti managed to expand the territory of Kastrioti's domain consisting of a couple of villages in the region of Debar by capturing the region of Mat.[27] After Gjon's subjugation to the Ottomans his former estates would be surveyed in Ottoman registers as Yuvan-ili.[28] One part of Gjon Kastrioti's domain comprising nine villages became a timar which was governed by Skanderbeg before it was granted to André Karlo in 1438, much to Skanderbeg's dismay.[29]
